habitat_description:
Northwest:
From CA WHR write-up: "The California red-backed vole is distributed in California from Marin Co. north to the Oregon border, and inland through Trinity Co., western Siskiyou Co., and northeastern Shasta Co. Also found from Plumas Co. north to southwestern Lassen Co. and southeastern Shasta Co. Locally common in riparian, red fir, subalpine conifer, Douglas-fir, lodgepole-pine, mixed conifer, Jeffrey-pine, montane hardwood-conifer, and redwood habitats with abundant ground cover and litter. Elevational range from sea level to 1900 m (6235 ft). Requires abundant ground cover of litter, slash, and logs. Most of life is spent under the forest floor, close to subterranean food sources (Maser et al. 1981)([Brylski et al. for CA WHR] based on Zeiner et al. 1990)." This semifossorial species is primarily found at low elevations within grasslands and wet meadows, and open oak savannah with abundant ground cover (Wilson and Ruff 1999). In Oregon, western red-backed voles are most abundant in closed-canopy, old-growth  forest with numerous downed logs - a critical habitat component (Doyle 1987, Gashwiler 1959, Maser and Maser 1988, Rosenburg et al. 1994, Tevis 1956). In the Coast Range, they occur in coniferous forests dominated by lodgepole pine, pacific rhododendron, Sitka spruce, salal, and red cedar (Maser et al. 1981, MacNab and Dirks 1941). In the Cascade Range, the highest abundances were located in climax Douglas-fir  and western hemlock forests with understories of Oregongrape, vine maple, rhododenron, and various forbs and shrubs (Gashwiler 1959, 1970). Doyle (1987) captured 2.5 times as many of this species in upland compared to riparian habitats and 3.9 times as many in forests >250 years old vs. those 100 years old (Verts and Carraway 1998).
